Okay, Slender Man was one of the most anticipated movie of 2018.. I enjoyed playing the game and listening to these urban legends about him, but this movie was.. EH!!!!
Just to know, this review is gonna be a funny review actually.

Slender Man is directed by Sylvain White, written by David Birke and starring Joey King, Julia Goldani Telles and Jaz Sinclair.

The story is about a group of girls summoning Slender Man and when he got summoned, one of them gets missing, and the others trying to run away from him.. this is the whole story!

Now, that's what I call a horror-pranks film, it's full of unscary scenes, with Slender Man pranking these girls.. or poor girls.. how did you talk all these pranks from a man without a face?

First of all, let's count the dumb choices in this movie...
1. They summoned Slender Man from a website, by a link says "SUMMON HIM". I mean what kind of creatures can be summoned from a website?
2. To "summon him", you must watch a video and follow the instructions in the video, and when you're done, congratulation, Slender Man is summoned, go and have fun with him!
3. Slender Man is a good pranker! He made me laugh a lot with his pranks... What's dumber than making a pranker creature in a horror movie?

4. Oh, yeah, the cast was dumber than Slender Man.

5. Slender Man, please, grow up.. stop playing with the trees, it's noisy!!

6. The CGI of Slender Man was like a man with some toilet paper rolled around his face.

7. This message is for the developers of this "game", please, fix the glitch of the faces, and the horror-dreaming stuff.

8. One more thing, please, fix the performances too, cause they are bad!

9. The finale.. LOL!

10. And now, the dumbest thing in the movie award goes to... The script! Congrats to the script, it was super-dumb!

WOW, this movie is terribly bad! As I said, it was one of the most anticipated movies of the whole year, but it disappointed me very very much! It easily became one of the worst movies of 2018 -if it's not the worst already-!

One more thing, why Katie's father thinks that "people can not just disappear"? Wake up, MR. There's something called kidnapping, didn't you hear about it?

I think you already know what I'm gonna give this terrible movie, don't you? Yup, it's definitely an F!!

So to put my experience with this movie in context: I have a long history with the Slender Man mythos. I came across some of the Marble Hornets videos back in 2010 or 2011, before the game came out and the character became sort of a meme, and I became obsessed. I poured through every webseries and blog I could find. Searched for forum threads of photoshops and did research on similar historical iconography. I even made my own short film on the subject. The community that was built around this monster was truly fascinating. An instantly recognizable monster whose stories were being built by a disorganized group of horror fans and amateur writers and filmmakers spread out across the internet. It was rapidly evolving modern folklore, and it was really cool to watch. Nearly the whole community seemed to understand what made Slender Man scary, and if they added context or back story, it would always be small and it would always raise more questions. The less you know about him the better. There were no solid rules. Just various accounts of stalking and death. Going back, a lot of this writing is fairly mediocre outside of the bubble of that passionate bunch of people, though some of the stuff still really holds up. One of my prized possessions is the complete series of Marble Hornets on DVD signed by the guys who made it. So with all that being said, I am going to address this film in two different ways: firstly as a film fan, and then as a Slender Man fan.

This is a very bad movie. Just atrocious. Wow. Do not watch it. Damn the writing is just so godawful. This is a movie about a bunch of teenage girls that was written by a middle-aged man and it is painful to watch. They spout weird dad jokes, and the flow of their conversations is so stilted and weird. They talk about leaving town in only the most generic, general ways. When Slender Man gets brought up, of course one of them has never heard of it, and the rest must explain it to her and the audience. They're all incredibly stupid. There's a scene where they all just have to sit still and wear blindfolds, and because the writing is trite garbage, one of them moronically lifts her blindfold and looks straight at the monster. Dumb. The drunken father of one of the girls breaks into his daughter's friend's house and attacks a couple of children and then is back in his home no problems the next day. Ridiculous. The whole set up and plot is basically a straight rip-off of The Ring. They watch a video, and then they are cursed to be killed by a monster. Plot threads are picked up and dropped almost instantly. There's a very pointed line about one girl having a bunch of trophies, and it's spoken with resentment. It sounds like a line you're supposed to remember but this almost conflict is never brought up again. There is a person feeding them information through the internet whose identity is called into question several times that stops being relevant halfway through the movie and they never address them again. The editing is choppy and the dream sequences are generic. The effects are inconsistent, sometimes they're creepy but usually they're in your face and looking awful. The sound design is full of odd choices. There is a sequence where she hears something downstairs and you hear metal clanking to the floor. This is later revealed to not be the monster, but I couldn't help but imagine Slender Man sneaking through the kitchen and accidentally knocking a pot off a shelf and it made me laugh in the middle of a scene that was supposed to be tense. Some of the cinematography was okay. The actors were alright, they probably would have been good if they had anything to work with, the cast really deserved better.

And as a Slender Man fan? What a mess. The writer and the director obviously have no concept of what makes this monster scary. Watching Slender Man videos trains you to watch the background for him. One of the scariest things about the character is seeing him when the protagonist doesn't. In Marble Hornets, the characters would become paranoid about doing things they don't remember and would film themselves when they sleep. Leading to recordings of Slender Man watching them while they lay unconscious. Characters would walk through the woods and you would catch a glimpse of him in the background. It increases the paranoia. He's always watching. In this movie the only time you see Slender Man is when the characters do. It's so blunt force about it. Wouldn't want the audience to miss him. Got to have him front and center. Wouldn't want to leave anything for someone to notice on a second viewing. Well, that's not fair really. I suppose there is one time where we see him and the girls don't; when his shadow sneaks into their room like he's fucking Peter Pan. It looks so stupid, and it's not even consistent with how he normally works. As someone who obsessively researched the Slender lore and got so freaked out by the videos that I would see him out of the corner of my eye next to trees and street poles, I can tell you that just finding the videos is enough to get someone hooked. That's what the community means when they say that he spreads like a virus. You find out about him and you go deeper and deeper and then you share your story and he spreads. Like a disease. The writer of this movie read the virus thing and instead decided to make it that Slender Man is "a computer virus but for your brain." Stupid. Nonsensical. So I suppose he did do some research, they showed a couple of the original Victor Surge images. They have the woodcarving of the skeleton. There's a brief mention of shadow people. But they obviously didn't do much more digging than that. And then there's the videos. They decided to rip off The Ring and make it so that instead of someone just becoming consumed by thoughts of Slender Man after finding videos or blog posts, there's a whole video-based summoning ritual that people do at parties. Sort of a modern Bloody Mary. Then well after that they find all of the drawings that are usually indicative of someone completely corrupted by Slender Man, a "proxy" as most people call it. But that doesn't actually make much sense for the character at that point, so it feels more like an element they knew they had to include but didn't know where to include it. All the videos they watch are strangely highly edited, with a whole lot of cuts and music playing over them and circles edited in to point out ol' Slendy, once again they have to point him out every time he's there because subtlety is impossible for this movie and it doesn't trust its audience to pay attention. And all these videos are posted on some deep web site. Why though? There's no violent content. Why are they not on a YouTube style website? You know, like they are in real life? And to cap it all off. Ever wonder what happens to Slender Man's victims after he takes them? Want to know what happens to these mysterious disappearing people? HE TURNS INTO A TREE AND THEN ABSORBS THEM INTO HIS TRUNK I GUESS.

OKAY. SURE. WHY NOT? FUCK IT.

It's just such a waste of a good monster. Slender Man can be terrifying, Marble Hornets frightened me more than any other horror media back when I first found it. But this movie is not remotely scary. Slender Man can be fascinating, finding all the little clues strewn about writing by dozens of different creators made me feel like I was uncovering some great secret. But the lore in this movie is so blunt force and expository it doesn't spur any curiosity. And ultimately, Slender Man can be great metaphor. He's been used as a way of addressing child abductions, self-medicating, our broken medical system, emotional isolation, mental illness, and fear of the wilderness. In this movie he is just a generic monster in a generic monster movie. He's the Bye Bye Man. He's Annabelle. He's It Follows, but shitty. Don't watch this movie. It's not a good movie.

My first encounter with Slender Man was with the freeware online game, Slender: The Eight Pages, that went viral back in 2012 scaring the bejesus out of everyone that played it. Actually, what dared me to play the game was the YouTube videos of people playing Slender, watching their reactions of nervous laughter and all out fear. So, this meant I went into the screening assuming this was a horror flick based on the phenomenal game, but sadly no, and as was exiting the cinema accusing the production team of not even having played the game, disrespecting it’s source material or totally missing out on some great potential. But, after a little research, I discover that the game itself was based on a recent folklore meme created by Eric Knudsen (credited as his pseudonym Victor Surge) back in 2009. It’s apart of this creepypasta movement that exploded via internet forums and chain letter style emails with copy and pasted (Hence the origin of creepypasta) images of folklore legends, many of which relating to ancient urban myths and horror stories. This being a competition to who could create the best paranormal images and so Slender Man was born in the Internet. I also discover that this isn’t the first film to feature Slender Man with an American found footage film Always Watching: A Marble Hornets Story which starred the famed, lanky and gaunt Doug Jones back in 2015. And there’s a number of smaller independent films and shorts based on Slender Man. I’ve yet to watch any of these films so it’s impossible for me to make any fair comparisons. So, I went in expecting a film based on the computer game and sadly was greeting with something totally uninspiring and unrelating apart from the scary no-faced character. But does knowing this might not have been inspired by the game make this film any better or forgivable? Hell, no! As a stand alone horror, it’s terribly executed and unoriginal, snatching bits from other horrors like The Ring in terms of myth and more recently the Autopsy of Jane Doe in terms of imagery. So, four girls hear about a scary video that claims to have some connection to children’s disappearances across the globe and so, they dare themselves to watch it during a sleepover, inviting a dark and sinister entity into their lives, the Slender Man. An urban legend that abducts children or sends them crazy with continually hauntings and nightmares. It’s a basic story which needn’t be trashed with poor performances or poor editing. I’m partly in conflict as to which owes more to the failure of this film, because their performances are no way aided by the obvious chopped up ending which would have an effect on the entire film. The trailers clearly indicates the film had some serious re-edits with so many loose ends that they couldn’t have been simply forgot about, because there’s some screenshots that hint at more of some of the character’s unfinished stories. But then I read about the controversy that spooked studios and distribution about promoting and even releasing the film. The Waukesha stabbing in 2014 where two 12year old girls stabbed a fellow classmate apparently to appease Slender Man and out of fear of him killing their families if they did not comply. When this film was announced, one of the fathers of the girls who committed the stabbing, urged local cinemas to refrain from showing the film, calling it “extremely distasteful” And this isn’t an isolated incident, there has been a number of acts of adolescent violence spurred on by the Slender Man myth. But ignoring the controversy, the film is poorly made and is not a good representation for director Sylvain White’s relatively small filmography. It’s super clichéd with bad plot lines, poorly acted and has such a weak script, and even weaker scares. The script and story are just plain stupid most of the time, again maybe owing a lot to bad edits, but no one would venture into dark woods, or walk the street alone at night when under threat. The imagery isn’t that terrible, trippy and subliminal at times but it’s nothing new and isn’t enough to save the film at all. Considering the amount of source material there is, and for me, just coming from the game; there’s so much potential that got sadly wasted and missed that makes me believe I could make a better Slender Man movie. Only thing I thought suited the film was some of the sounds, the tolling bells and the looming hum. This film is begging for a spoof, especially when one character prematurely expresses his sex face. It’s just one of the worse horrors I’ve seen lately, it’s one of the worse films I’ve ever seen. In a small town in Massachusetts, a group of friends, fascinated by the internet lore of the Slender Man, attempt to prove that he doesn't actually exist... until one of them mysteriously goes missing.

Alright, alright, I'm a little intoxicated right now. But so what? I mean if anything, I did this backwards. I felt like this is the kind of movie that I'd have to be intoxicated to watch, but I feel really mean saying that...so, let's not say that! Instead, let's just say that this is definitely one of the worst movies I've seen this year. 

I don't really know where to start and I don't want to spend much time on this but let's get started. The screenplay is probably the worst thing about this film. I can tell this is the kind of film that was pushed out really quickly to make bank, but it came out a few years too late. This screenplay didn't really have a beginning, middle and end. The characters weren't given any distinctive quality traits that separated them from one another. There were obviously a couple of cool ideas here but it was just so rushed. It was an hour and a half but it flew by like a bullet. 

The other problem was that this film was mostly written in post. Most of its intense, 'scary' scenes were rapidly cut together and paired with bright flashing lights, iffy sound design, and lackluster animation. I felt like the editors were trying to sculpt something out of nothing and it just wasn't there. It sucks because the actors weren't too bad but this film tried to make scares out of nothing. 

To be honest I'd rather get back to drinking so I'm going to cut this review short. I normally write reviews to help myself become a better writer but I don't feel the need to elaborate more on this. Cheers!

As a former moderator on a creepypasta website, this is by far the funniest film I have ever seen. The established canon being torn to pieces, the cliche and overdone orchestral jumpscares and plot, and the complete lack of any substance had me busting my gut in laughter. Almost seeming like a parody of the mythos, this film is a must-see for anyone interested in creepypasta, just for the raw comedic value.

As it stands on its own, though, without any ironic enjoyment, the film is utter garbage. Four nondescript boring leads in a town that apparently has never heard of light switches, flashlights, or common sense, embarking on a soulless, incoherent plot about kidnappings, brain viruses that are like computer viruses(?), and the corniest acting and scenes this side of the millennium. If you want a genuinely good horror flick, then this movie will make you either fall asleep or contemplate jumping off a building.

The original creator of The Slender Man would (and probably is) be so heartbroken to see his creation that started off as a creepy photoshop contest, spawn hundreds of creepy pasta stories, became a video game success, and become one of the most horrifying urban legends of its time utterly fail in this poor excuse of a movie adaptation. Directors nd writers put no though or energy into this at all. It was cheesy, predictable, and downright boring. All this was, was a simple cash grab piggybacking off of someone else's success. Yet another great character ruined by laziness.

If there was ever a time to capitalize on the creepy internet sensation of Slender Man, it would be, well, not now in 2018. Maybe seven or eight years ago, definitely not several years after the tendrilled, blank-faced figure hit peak popularity, and definitely not after a poor girl was assaulted by two impressionable young girls in his name only four years back. Well, here's Slender Man now, a terrible movie adaptation of an already worn premise that's torturous to watch in every single way imaginable.
You know exactly what kind of movie you're in for within the first few dialogues of Slender Man. The four "teenage" girls speak like they're forty-year-old men reciting their best Generation Z impressions, all while giving the spooky trees surrounding them a solid run contending for the film's most wooden performances. Lead character Hallie (Julia Goldani Telles) is an especially boring black hole of charisma that's impossibly hard to root for given her next-level stupidity and complete void of personality.
Where there's no logic in Slender Man's character development (which it doesn't really have to begin with), there's even less in its titular big bad. With the abilities to appear in dreams/visions, manipulate tree trunks and tree branches (?), as well as haunt social medias in a shameless rip-off of The Ring, none of the Slender Man's powers have any sort of correlation, sense, or palpable installation of fear. Also, he's got tentacles.
Really, unless you're thirteen years old and on some early 2010's scene, there's nothing scary about a very tall man without a face wearing a ([n] admittedly dapper) business suit. Apart from some truly horrid VFX more than a notch below the quality of a student film, the only frights arrive by way of the cheapest of the most leading of choreographed of jump scares harbored in inappropriately messy, nonsensible horror sequences.
Perhaps the most insulting part of Slender Man is the moral haphazardly slapped onto the epilogue. In a tasteless attempt at justifying its controversial existence, the film's closing monologue involves a character describing Slender Man's true powers as a virus preying on curiosity, specifically online obsession. It's an obvious nod to the 2014 tragedy in which two girls stabbed their friend to near death as an offering for the fictional online creation, but it's downright offensive the film thinks it has something important to say.
With awful acting, writing, directing, storytelling, and every other imaginable aspect that goes into movie-making, Slender Man is a film that lands dead on arrival. There's not even a trace of ironic fun to be had with it.

Slender Man is based off online stories about the titular supernatural being whose fame was born 9 years ago and died about as far back. In the film, a group of girls decide to summon the Slender Man to prove he doesn't exist, but when one of them disappears all hell breaks loose. 



Find a comfy seat, settle in, and try not to fall asleep as Slender Man is so thin there's barely enough substance to keep you awake. Nothing about this past the 15 minute mark is at all engaging. It starts off quite well where it does a fine job introducing its protagonists, setting up the legend behind the Slender Man character, and had me keen to see where it ends up heading. But where it goes isn't scary, suspenseful, or even barely interesting... it's a straight up bore and going into the third act I was fighting to stay awake. It progresses so agonisingly slow and the occasional attempt at a horror sequence rips away any suspense as oppose to introducing it. There really isn't much variety to the horror sequences either, one or two moments are unique in that they're not going straight for the jump-scare but rather the presence of something creepy in the background.

As time goes on and the Slender Man starts becoming more physically involved in the horror sequences it becomes even less scary. It's one of those situations in horror where I feel like a less-is-more approach would have worked much better in generating scares. Any time it looked like it was starting to build suspense it completely ruins it with a predictably timed jump-scare or by simply showing the Slender Man which completely took me out of the film every time.



I want to highlight the editing here which is at times absolutely shocking and also the basic progression of the story that at times didn't make sense from scene to scene. Some of the editing and scene transitions are noticeably dreadful and jarring to the point where I couldn't tell what I was watching in some action/horror sequences because of jarring rapid cuts. And it's not just the editing within sequences that's awful, it genuinely feels like at times entire scenes are missing as it cuts from one location to the next and I'm straight up lost. For instance, as I mentioned in the premise a girl goes missing, when this happens in the movie one second it's day time and she's there and then in literally the next scene it's late afternoon and she's now missing. It took me a bit of time to gather what had happened and it's not the only transition that is dreadfully executed. And then I did a bit of research and found that Bloody Disgusting is reporting that major scenes were cut from the film by Sony/Screen Gems in fear of backlash to their gruesome nature. 



As far as the performances go, none of them really stand out as being any good. The four lead teens are played by Joey King, Annalise Basso, Julia Goldani Telles, and Jaz Sinclair and none of them really make an impact. Annalise Basso is the one I'm most familiar with as she was great in both Captain Fantastic (2016) and Ouija: Origin of Evil (2016). However she really isn't given much to do and I'd say is wasted in the story. Joey King I didn't really enjoy in here, she didn't really sell me on the situations her character was in, and this only adds to her questionable year with her role in Netflix's The Kissing Booth which isn't good in the traditional sense. Julia Goldani Telles I'd say contributes the most to the film in that I found her character at the very least slightly engaging and at times was rooting for her specifically to succeed. She sold me the most on the horror of some sequences so I guess there's one positive. 



I wouldn't suggest Slender Man to anyone, even if you were a fan of the legend 8 years ago this doesn't offer much content to scare you and is ultimately severely disappointing. There's a real lack of suspense and terror in the film with only the first 15 minutes being effective and a very small handful of scenes that followed actually bearing a tense nature. Watching this is a waste of time, time that could be spent towards an actually good horror movie that'll scare you as oppose to putting you to sleep.

Slender Man Review: Slender Man tells the story of three high school girls who summon Slender Man through “a website video” (because they can’t say YouTube or anything), a monster that looks like a pale, tall man with freakishly long arms and no face, after watching porn at a sleepover and there’s a lot of screaming and jump scares. Wow this was a terrible movie. I never expected much in the first place. When they first announced that the movie would be made I thought maybe they could make a decent horror movie out of it. Then the first trailer arrived. It was a bunch of random creepy images and didn’t even involve Slender Man at all. That’s when I knew it would receive horrible reviews. It currently has an 11% on Rotten Tomatoes, 29 on Metascore, and 3/10 on IMDb. The plot was horrible. Very predictable, a bunch of jump scares, stupid decisions, and many laughable moments. The cast was horrible except for Annalise Basso, who is actually a good actress. But the order of disappearances for the girls goes from best actress to worst actress. Because of that the whole ending was so painful to watch. It was pretty funny to watch. The last 5ish minutes was hilarious. Because I don’t care I’m going to spoil it. The girl we’re left with is freaking out because of everything that’s been happening so she goes to the woods to give her life to Slender Man so it can all end. When Slender Man goes in to full monster mode to take her she runs away screaming. Like a few seconds ago she wanted to give her life. Another hilarious moment with that girl is there’s a part where she goes over to this one guy’s house and they’re about to have sex. She looks at his face and it’s violently shaking with a smile and the room is spinning and she’s screaming. It was one of the funniest scenes in a movie I’ve seen all year. The last dumb scene I’ll talk about came earlier in the movie. Annalise (the good actress) went missing and the three girls go into the woods at night to get rid of something they love as a sacrifice to Slender Man so they can get her back. The girls are supposed to be blindfolded and not to look because if they see his face they’ll be messed up forever. Of course one of the girls gets scared so she takes off her blindfolds and sees him, which had horrible effects and looked dumb. Then it’s just a bunch of screaming and tripping through the woods followed by fake jump scares. There is not much good I can say about the movie. The only things are that Annalise was a good actress for the 15 minutes she was in the movie and there was maybe two instances where it was sort of creepy. Honestly it could’ve been a good movie if they did a plot similar to the video game, like a found footage thing with the plot of the game. Instead we got some funny jumbled movie with bad acting from Julia Goldani Telles and Joey King (who has been in horrible horror movies recently). This movie is going to win some Razzie Awards for sure. Don’t see it. Don’t waste your money. If you want to watch laughable horror film then this is the movie for you. My Grade: D

Let me start out by telling you that I went to see this with some family members and my Dad actually fell asleep during the movie...
This movie is terrible, the only reasons I gave it half a star is because the camera work was really interesting and pretty okay, and the website won't let me give it zero stars.
The acting is terrible and unconvincing, the plot was empty, the story went barely anywhere, and the ending is abrupt and leaves a lot of loose ends. I have to say, the only thing that "scared" me was the noise and music build up to the jumpscares, but once you get into the rhythm of the movie it's not scary at all, because you expect the jumpscares, and that's really the only scary thing this movie has got going for it. One of the other issues I had was the lighting. I understand it's supposed to be a dark, scary movie with silhouettes and shadows, but some sets were so dark that you couldn't see what was actually happening. The other lighting extreme was when a character would be walking in a dark place and suddenly shine their LED phone torch right down the barrel of the camera. If the effect of this was to temporarily blind you, then it's spot on.
A few things in this movie actually made me laugh, like some of the scenes, acting, and a couple of the jump scares even made me giggle.
The only good thing about this movie was the camera work. There were parts of the movie where characters were experiencing hallucinations and nausea, and the camera work did an excellent job of portraying that feeling to the audience. Apart from that, it is not worth the cost of pop corn and tickets.
Overall, this movie is boring, cringey, too long, and uneventful. The acting, although hilarious at times, was unconvincing. I recommend saving your money and skipping this "horror" movie.

Just to preface, I don't feel good about criticizing Slender Man. It feels like telling a kindergartener that their fingerpainting is lazy and derivative. I wasn't expecting too much going into this movie. And within the first 10 minutes, I gathered enough to know that the movie didn't want you to expect much of it, either. I like to lump movies like this into a category I call Sleepover Horror, along with recent gems like Bye Bye Man, Wish Upon, and Truth or Dare. Sleepover Horror does not hold itself to very high standards and asks that audiences do the same. The only standard is that it must be PG-13, catering to young adolescents who want to be spooked with their friends under a pile of blankets on the couch on Saturday night. To be frank, I have a soft spot for these kinds of movies. My first forays into horror were films just like these from a previous era (circa The Grudge). And when you're 13, you don't know or care that they're mediocre; they deliver what you and your friends want. So I would never grade Slender Man with the same rubric as something like Hereditary. Apples and oranges.

But even the nostalgia of my younger years couldn't redeem this failed attempt at movie making. I actually think it started out fairly promising. The premise was good enough, the characters were good enough, and the atmospheric tension was good enough (also, props to Joey King for acting her heart out no matter what script she's handed). For me, the biggest stake in the heart of this movie was pacing. When we're dealing with Sleepover Horror, I can forgive a lot: bad acting, ridiculous dialogue, painful plot contrivances, exposition through text messages, etc. But I can't forgive boredom, which Slender Man dished out in full service. I was along for the ride until Hallie's date with Tom: perfectly fine scene, but I have no recollection of what happened after that. I blacked out. I can't remember anything, because nothing in the following scenes made any sense plot-wise and therefore blurred together in a feverish attempt to mimic "The Ring." I came to around the part where Wren's trying to jump out her window for some reason, but by that point, I was no longer invested. If Slender Man had shaved 15 minutes off of its runtime and trimmed some of its fat, I think I might have held out until the end. It was a 90-minute movie that felt much, much longer.

Not to pile more dirt on its grave, but I have a list of other minor issues with Slender Man that I want to get off my chest:

I don't even know if the writer's originally planned this script with Slender Man in mind as the Big Bad. The fact that it's called Slender Man is totally meaningless; the film barely addresses any of his lore. It may as well have been called Spooky Steve, or Creepy Creeper, or Bye Bye Man 2. If you're going to make a movie specifically about Slender Man, you should probably draw upon what made him creepy in the first place. Like how he's always stoically planted in the background; he never moves and you never see him up close. That shit can be really effective for spooks (see "Courage the Cowardly Dog" episode with Ramses and the slab). As soon as we see him up close, he's robbed of his power. He seemed like a ripoff of the Crooked Man from Conjuring 2, both in the way he looked and moved.

Not to harp on the mythos, but didn't they explicitly mention that Slender Man has the power to hypnotize his victims and lure them in? That seemed to work with Katie, but the other girls were lure-proof. They kept screaming and running away. Hallie even has a weird moment at the end where she's like "Take me, sir. I'm ready to die" and then immediately changes her mind and bolts.

Why did the nurses in the hospital wear old-timey uniforms?

This movie has a real lighting problem. Most of it is in so much shadow that you can't see the actors' faces (intentional?), and then it'll suddenly cut to, like, the surface of the sun. For viewers in a dark theater, this was torture (and it happened about every 5 minutes). Like in the woods scene, when they have flashlights and then shine their lights right into the camera and it feels like you're in a dentist's chair.

They couldn't decide who it's protagonist was. My vote would be for the younger sister Lizzy since she gets a great little voiceover at the end that attempts to tie things together with the final word "ya know?"

Hallie is always mentioning she has track practice but never goes to track practice. What are you hiding, Hallie?

Hallie's family dinner is really quiet, dark, and awkward. I hate when movies do this. Hereditary did it too, but it had the excuse that a huge tragedy had just occurred. Wouldn't you at least want to turn on a few lights and play some light dinner jazz?

Obligatory library research scene. Why was Wren there? She was just using the computer; does she not have one of those at home? Also, I really wanted to the librarian to play a more central role, like in Bye Bye Man.

I think the director was trying to imitate The Ring with all the fog and bluish tones, but I was getting some heavy Twilight vibes, especially with all the forest scenes. I was waiting for a sexually charged scene between Hallie and Slender Man where she's like, "How old are you?" and "How long have you been 17?"

This movie was absolutely terrible. It was like someone gave a very, very, VERY vague description of what Slenderman is, and the writers were like "Oh, yeah, that makes sense." It relief on cheap jump scares and only mildly creepy seizure-enducing "hallucinations" for its horror factor. The acting was terrible, the special effects were terrible, the characters were terrible. I wish I could get my money back.

Overall, this movie was garbage and a waste of my money. Before going to see this film, I had already predicted that it would be some cheesy and atrocious film rendition of the game Slender Man. Needless to say, my prediction was spot on. First of all, the timing for the release of this movie is way off. The movie should've been released when the urban legend of Slender Man was in its prime. Other than that, the story was extremely boring, cliche, and often times very predictable. Another cliche aspect of the film were its "horror" features. Slender Man was riddled with predictable jump scares and little to no psychological aspects. There were only a couple parts that truly scared me. When it came to the atmosphere, the film was okay at best. The dark and foggy forest, Slender Man's home, was truly creepy. This was partly complemented by the sound design including the blowing of leaves and the creaking of branches. However, these scenes still didn't make up for the atrocious overuse of jump scares. Another thing I was disappointed with was the acting. It wasn't the worst in the world, but it certainly wasn't great. Acting is really supposed to sell the plot to the viewer and make the movie more interesting, but the acting in this movie didn't appeal to me or make the movie's already boring plot interesting. It lacked substance and didn't really make the characters memorable. Speaking of characters, the character development in this film was awful. The four main characters were just your typical high school girls seeking adventure. As I've said before, there is nothing memorable about these characters. Lastly, I'd like to touch upon the editing. Everything was fine except the CGI. The CGI was horrendous and made the movie much worse than it already was. A simple solution to this would be to show the main villain less. Reason being because it wouldn't showcase the limited CGI effects and also introduce a more eerie, psychological horror-type aspect into the movie. Great horror flicks like The Blair Witch Project (1999) have done this and I don't see why this film can't. Overall, I believe this movie was outdated for its time, boring, predictable, and simply just a bad movie.

The plot dragged on for too long, with too few scares or reasons to care about the fate of the film's characters. Even worse, the lighting is so dark (even during daylight scenes) that I could barely see what was happening on the screen. There was barely any tension present in the film, as it failed to offer a frightening incarnation of the usually frightening creepypasta legend. 

The PG-13 rating is not the problem with the film. Other horror films with the family friendlier rating have proven effective at offering thrills and chills without tons of violence or gore (such as Poltergeist, Truth or Dare, and A Quiet Place) so please don't blame the MPAA rating for this film's faults.

I think what ultimately killed Slenderman was the studio and the distributor's fear of OFFENDING a society that THRIVES ON BEING OFFENDED. Naturally, the people that might take offense wouldn't watch it anyway, so it is the audience that ultimately pays the price. 2018 is the year of "finding something to be offended by", and the film's backers fell into this societal fad. 

I sincerely hope horror's recent return to the mainstream isn't further strangled by the "hashtag" society of prudes and wannabe victims that have pulverized the entertainment industry to the point where every movie and TV show feels like a political advertisement. 

Bottom line: Wait for an unrated home video release for this one...If there is one.

The worst thing about how utterly bad this film is, is how wonderful the cinematography (in spite of the horrible CGI and horrid script) and the Soundtrack were. They had so much potential to be utilized with slender man, but made so many horrible choices with the liberties taken on the Lore. The acting borders from, “ok” to “shamefully bad”, and the script was just horrendous. It’s so all over the place, and the potholes grow larger every minute. The film also suffers from trying to stay tame in order to keep the rating safe for kids to be able to attend. It goes so far down the safety hole that it’s almost more PG than PG-13. There’s no gore, sex, or nudity. The only thing I can think of to maybe justify Pg-13 over PG is that one kid says, “fuck” once. (They say “frick” other times... seriously) it’s just way too timid, and it borders on being flat out boring. The often beautiful shots (when they’re not raped by hideously cheap CGI) and fantastic soundtrack are all that kept me from passing out into a boredom induced coma. They repeatedly try for the cliche jump scares, but you see them a mile off. It just fails on so many levels, and it’s frustrating because at the root of it all, they really could’ve made something brilliant if they hadn’t succumbed to being lazy, safe, and cliche. I’d say a generous 4 out of 10 (i hate 5 star ratings)and only for the cinematography and score which really are wasted on a turd of a film. The rest is just a sloppy mess.

It's a reiteration of the vast majority of recent horror movies. Cringe-worthy "relatable" teens make poor decisions to further the story of an otherwise plotless movie. This steaming pile of poop is an uninspired cash-grab simply taking advantage of a household name to lure in viewers (seven years too late). If ten people see this movie, it will probably surpass the budget and make the producers a profit.  Utilizing a cast of future porn stars and prior homeless people (because who else would star in it), Slender Man is sure to make slender earnings in the box office.

A couple years ago, Slender Man, the fictional monster created by Eric Knudsen, came to the forefront of American culture. The creepy fiction inspired two adolescent girls to complete an act of ruthless violence that was more terrifying than any story. A quick search of the character reveals numerous accounts of the way this 21st-century boogie man abducts children. These stories are often accompanied with photoshopped images of the figure throughout history, adding to the mystery and allure of the character. 

It was only a matter of time before Hollywood would try to profit off of the character, so naturally, this Slender Man film was born. The film follows a group of high school students who accidentally summon Slender Man into their world. They watch a bizarre internet video filled with spooky shots of forests, pagan looking symbols, and otherworldly bells. Honestly, this reminded me of the VHS tape that is played in The Ring. A week later, one of the girls goes missing, and the rest of the group must face the Slender Man to try to get her back. 

For being based upon a character that has inspired so much imagined and real-life horror, Slender Man the movie isn't very scary. The film is plagued by horror movie cliche after cliche and an ending that was so inevitably mundane that I left the theater wondering why I had even bothered. Save for the wonderfully atmospheric shots and creepy forest settings, there really aren't many redeeming qualities to the film. We see this CGI monster far too often for us to really be scared of the unknown of it. Instead of getting behind the characters as they try to investigate the mythology and motivation of the Slender Man, I spent more time rolling my eyes at their terrible judgment and cringe-worthy dialogue.  There was a real opportunity to craft a modern horror classic based upon what is arguably one of the most terrifying spooks in recent years. What we get instead is a boring and uninspired movie that will have even the most die-hard horror fans wishing they had kept Slender Man away from the big screen.

It has its moments, but Slender Man is ultimately a dull affair.

What is really disappointing is that the first ten minutes or so are pretty good. We are introduced to the four main characters. (One of the positive points of Slender Man is its actors.) The dialogue and pacing is pretty good, but then things just fall apart. There are a lot of dull scenes of the characters talking, arguing, and investigating without much interaction with anyone else. It doesn't help that the rules to Slender Man are vague and confusing throughout, and the exposition is delivered haphazardly. The ending in particular is a muddled mess.

To its credit, the actual scares in this are pretty good. They do manage to capture what makes the Slender Man so scary in the first place. There are some really impactful visuals. The director is an artist when it comes to spooky forests and having Slender Man fading in and out of the background. (Although on the other hand, there is an annoyingly large amount of close-ups.)

As spooky and nice looking as this movie can be, the good bits are just too few and far apart. I can't recommend this.

Urban Legends are things that every middle school and high school kid, as far back as I can remember, have perpetuated through word-of-mouth and online rumors and storytelling in ways that are meant to inspire a sense of mystery and, in most cases, horror through describing beings and encounters just fantastic enough to be interesting while being close enough to reality to be truly frightening. The Slender Man is no different. I am in my mid-twenties and, from what I can remember, I first heard about the Slender Man phenomenon around my junior year of high school (2011). At the time, my younger middle school-aged brother was the type of kid that couldn’t watch even the tamest horror movie without pissing himself. Some of his friends at school had told him about a tall guy with no face that would kidnap you if you stayed out too late (I’m paraphrasing). One night when we were leaving the local rec center, not even 500 yards from our front door, he downright demanded that we call our mom to get a ride home because, in his words, “It’s too dark out. The Slender Man could come get us on the way.” This was, to me, the dumbest thing I had heard out of his mouth in a while, but I asked for details and he told me what he knew. I thought that this sounded like a cool story. Some supernatural tall guy that comes outta nowhere and steals kids during the night? I’m in. A movie based on this story could go one of a hundred different directions. They could have gone the ultra out-there route and had the Slender Man end up being an alien abducting people (The Fourth Kind, anyone?). They could have made a found footage movie (for less money), also in the woods, similar to the storyline we got, but in a more grounded way with way less computer and phone screen exposition. What did we get, you ask? (this is the part where you get my actual review) We got a 90-minute sequence of teenage girls looking back and forth from each other to their (Sony) phone/computer screens followed by 45 minutes of a CGI tree monster facetiming people before ultimately kidnapping them. There are some decent attempts at fear-inducing imagery early on in the film, many of which were heavily influenced by (read “ripped off of”) the Ring franchise, but nothing we haven’t seen done before, better. Character development is almost non-existent. We know one girl’s dad is an alcoholic (though it never plays into the plot) and another girl runs/ran track. That is the extent of an attempt made at fleshing out any of the characters in this movie. Many of the sequences taking place in old buildings or in the woods used sound to their advantage and were definitely high points in the theater experience. The notion that something might sneak up behind you after a crunching of leaves or creaking of floorboards is a whole hell of a lot more relatable and frightening than much of the on-screen CGI-heavy visuals in the final act. The ending of the movie, which I will not spoil here for those of you who have been waiting your whole lives for a Slender Man feature film, was one of the most rushed, laziest endings I have seen in a very long time. This leaves the viewer annoyed and ultimately willing to forget any of the slightly more positive areas of the experience in favor of remembering the movie for what it is; a forgettable throw-away with a solid concept wasted on bad storytelling, mediocre acting, and a closing sequence that would drop a student film a whole letter grade.

To say this film was mediocre would be the understatement of the millennium. "Slender Man" is the reason why moviegoers today are losing so much faith in the modern horror genre. ("A Quiet Place" is an immensely better 2018 horror flick.) People say Hollywood lacks originality these days, and you really can't blame them, especially when Sony of all companies makes a film based on an Internet creepypasta... from 2012.

I have a theory: had this film been made at the height of the Slenderman phenomenon 6 years ago, the effect would've been a bit stronger, and the film would've probably done slightly better at the box office. (This film has only been out for a day and I don't see it staying in theaters for more than a month.)

And now for the actual movie. The acting isn't too horrible, but that's not even the main issue. Any frightening characteristics still associated with our old pal Slendy are now gone. Rather than have our sharp-dressed antagonist be a horrifying, rarely-seen stalker that watches you from afar, they've made him into a physically destructive, confrontational, borderline-slasher villain, like a paranormal Michael Myers. Other than his trademark suit, nothing about this movie truly says SLENDER MAN. Not even the infamous circle-and-X logo makes an appearance. Even Slendy's edgy fanboy Masky is absent. (Fans of the "Marble Hornets" franchise will understand.)

Speaking of which, if you want a more effective and unsettling picture about this jaded internet meme, go watch the "Marble Hornets" videos on YouTube. The 2015 feature-length spin-off "Always Watching" is almost as bad as the 2018 film, so pick your poison, dear viewer.

In conclusion, getting murdered by Slendy would've been far less painful than this 93-minute embarrassment of moving pictures.

CreepyPastas. Love'em or hate'em, they're here to stay. And the one that spawned this film is one of the first & best!

SLENDER MAN.

This particular tale started out as a short story on the net. From there, it blossomed into a national phenomenon, in good ways, & bad. Does this film do ol' Slendy justice? I would say....a little, but not fully.

Despite being 1 & a half hours long, it felt a lot longer, it crept along at a snails pace which, I'm sorry to say, hurt the film overall. There were good parts, to be sure, but it took FOREVER to get to them! The film's atmosphere was that of a modern gothic mystery, but then it de-evolved into a cliché slasher flick without the boobs or gore!

The cast did well with what they were given which, sadly, wasn't much. I did believe they were a group of semi-misfit teens who messed with something they didn't fully understand till it was too late. I just wish these young starlets had been given better material, better direction....really, just a better movie. They were given half a can of corn starch & 3 packets of hot sauce & told to make a meal, & they managed to make something at least edible.

The effects were fine, but not enough to save the film. Slendy looked as he was supposed to, & there were parts where reality was distorted in a way that made you question what you were seeing.

The music was generic, but harmless. The sound effects were a good blend of harsh tones & white noise meant to disorient & set your jaw on edge so you didn't know what to expect, it was a moderate high point.

Sadly, I can't recommend Slender Man to any hard core Slendy fans. All the elements are there, but there's just....something missing. It's like the difference between regular candy & soda, & the sugar free & diet stuff, mainly the aftertaste. It's not an insult to the Slender Man, because it's not even on his radar; it's a generic ghost story that someone crammed Slendy into, which resulted in, not a bang, not a whimper, but a dull "...meh." I have no choice, but to give it 2.5 stars outta 5. See it once for the curiosity; but once you see it.....it'll be pretty easy to un-see it.

Slender Man is truly one of the worst films I've seen in years.  The writing is clunky and on par with a first draft, the acting is stiff and phoned in, and there's little sense of direction to be found anywhere in the movie.  Slender Man himself looks like he's wearing a sock over his head.  Unfortunately, this movie is a complete flop in the horror department as well.  When they're not unintentionally funny, the scares are mostly flat and lame (but don't worry, the movie compensates with obnoxiously loud music).  Even if you get scared at first, you probably won't get scared by the end, because this movie is as repetitive as all get out.  As an example, there's a certain scene in which a character gets scared by Slender Man and then wakes up in bed, only to immediately get scared and wake up again.  Seriously.  It's enough to make me wonder if this film is intentionally bad, because I can't imagine that anyone who was making this film thought this was passable.  Above all, this "movie" is a feeble attempt to cash in on an internet trend that faded into obscurity long before the movie came out.

Despite knowing this movie would be bad well before watching it, as a horror fan and teen growing up when this modern myth circulated the internet, I had to watch it... To my surprise, not only did a big budget studio poorly adapt an indie style concept, but they gave it little to no budget that only gave them limited locations to film with, but almost no resources for believable CGI, as Slender Man itself, this film's flagpole monster, is so glaringly fake that even potentially good scares fell flat on their faceless visage.

If you want Slender Man, watch one of the many fan films/series on YouTube for not only a higher quality experience, but a more soundly investment of your money with cheap scares.

You ever been so angry by a film that you have to create a Rotten Tomatoes account?  Well, neither have I until I saw this utter piece of cinematic garbage. The performances were predominantly well done and the dialogue was not terrible.

The CGI was not terrible and was scarcely used, excluding the climax of the film, which unfortunately suffered from using the CGI so confidently on such a small budget.

The cinematography was well done in many scenes and made surprisingly well done transitions.

The film, however, was not scary. Well, not in the ordinary way that many people define it.

The film had many jumpscares, which unfortunately were very predictable and not very heart pounding at all. But it did scare in another way. 

It made me afraid in my own home. The fear of your safety being violated is something this film preys upon successfully. Although my heart wasn't pounding from suspense, I was instead incredibly paranoid when I returned to my own home. Some of the encounters are very well done, and many of them were in public or private places where danger would seem to be the least of your worries.

This film is different. It has some big plot holes and some iffy cgi, but the atmosphere and the lingering paranoia really sold it for me. 

Unfortunately not many may agree with me, due to the negative publicity the film recieved due to its origins.

'slender man' is the worst movie I have ever seen. the acting is terrible, the writing is horrible, the directing is embarrassing. Sylvain white should never be allowed near a film production ever again. slender man is a popular character yet is utilized worse than the bye bye man. great opportunities missed in this unoriginal ripoff of truth or dare and the ring. the cinematography is so ugly and dark, it's hard to see most of the movie, and when you can see it it's ugly to look at. the camera shots are so lifeless, sometimes you ponder why sylvain white placed the camera where he did. the storyline doesn't make any sense, you don't know how much time has passed in the movie since randomly it's day and night. the source material is not respected in the slightest as slender man is barely in the movie and is not scary, he is utilized terribly. this movie isn't scary, jumpscares aren't scary, they're a cheap scare, and even those are barely in the movie. it's so predictable. this movie is however funny and should be seen as a comedy, the scares are so poorly done and unintentionally funny, the audience in my theater were laughing. the script is clearly written by someone who doesn't understand how teenagers talk or act. the first 20 minutes feel like an hour and is boring and the rest is funny and quick. if you do go see this movie, see it with a friend or something as this would suck to watch alone. Slender Man fails at being a horror movie, but it unintentionally may be the laugh-out-loud comedy of the year. Where to begin? I guess we can start with the acting. You know how there's that horror movie cliche where the characters wearingSlender Man fails at being a horror movie, but it unintentionally may be the laugh-out-loud comedy of the year. Where to begin? I guess we can start with the acting. You know how there's that horror movie cliche where the characters wearing the least amount of clothes die at the beginning, but the surviving characters lose more and more clothing as the movie goes on? Well, Slender Man is like that, but if the acting got worse as the movie goes on. I mean, there is some intense scenery chewing from our leading ladies. To put it bluntly, the script is a lazy mess. It doesn't follow it's own rules for how Slender Man behaves. Characters say and do random things that are never brought up again (like the main character being on the track team, which is never ever used by the story). Some scenes read like an emo highschool girl's BDSM fantasy. Several scenes rip off of Marble Hornets very poorly. There are several "dream-within-a-dream" scenes that are laughable at best and boring at worst. In fact, that's a good analogy for this whole movie. Half of the movie is hilarious and the other half put me to sleep!Now for Slender Man himself. Sometimes he looks like a bloke wearing a tube sock on his head. Other times he looks absolutely T H I C C. Like, this guy has some hips that just don't quit. He's not very slender at all! Also, some of his effects look like the crew for Birdemic came in and did the CGI. There's a shot of him standing in the woods in broad daylight with UNFINISHED tentacle renders floating behind him. Also, there's a chase scene at the very end of the movie that looked like a PS1 era cutscene. It was so cringey it was a riot.The soundtrack is the only saving grace of this film. Ramin Djwadi did the music, and there are some good horror vibes and ambient noises. The end credit music is easily the best music in the film, although that may have been colored by how happy I was for Slender Man to finally be over. This is a GREAT bad movie to watch with friends. If you actually like being scared, just don't.

I watched this movie with a friend of mine who wanted to see it. I had no interest in watching it, but she did and I wanted to go because I guess it might have been at least funny. And it kind of was. We were basically ripping on it, makingI watched this movie with a friend of mine who wanted to see it. I had no interest in watching it, but she did and I wanted to go because I guess it might have been at least funny. And it kind of was. We were basically ripping on it, making our own MST3K commentary on the film. There were two other people in the theater, and I'm pretty sure they were on a date night and we both ruined it. Suffice to say we both had a fun time watching it. And honestly if I wasn't watching it with her and making fun of it, I would probably be a lot madder at this movie. Because regardless of the viewing experience, the hype is real! This movie is as bad as people made it out to be! Like I thought that maybe I can find a positive about this film, but honestly it's been a long time since I've seen a movie that is fundamentally broken! Like I cannot think of a single thing about this movie that worked! Maybe there are some creepy imagery that worked, but there are far better horror films with the same imagery that work a lot better! I guess the sound design is also kind of decent too, if you ignore all the stock sound effects. Other than that, nothing!The acting is horrible! Like not a single actor in this movie is good! They are all terrible! But I mean even with good actors could not save the writing of these "characters!" None of them get developed! They are all interchangeable suburban teenage girls, except one is apparently a track star, one has red hair, one's black, and one looks like a cross between Regan from the Exorcist and Chloe Grace Moretz! There's no main character as the movie shifts around the four leads but they all act the same! It's basically one spirit character of whine and whimper and make faces that probably look like they are scared! The directing is **** Not only did director Sylvian White not direct the actors to be good, but so much of the framing and shot composition is **** He couldn't make a movie scary because it is filled with jump scares! Nothing but jump scares! There are creepy imagery, but it is blatant how hard the movie wants to be the Ring of the YouTube generation! The editing is also bad, making the timeline of events confusing and jarring! The rules also do not make sense! One of the scenes have the girls give up something precious to them, but they have to be blindfolded to do so and not take it off to look at Slender Man, or else you'll go nuts. Well one of the girls did, and yet they all start going crazy? Like Slender Man is a troll! Speaking of him, if you are afraid of ****ty CGI monsters, then do not watch this movie! Otherwise the Slender Man looks stupid and ridiculous! The plot drags out as not much happen! It's not even a fun movie to watch on it's own it's just a drag to watch!It's not like a Slender Man movie can be good. Because it can be, but there was no way a Hollywood adaptation of the Internet legend would be anything but bull****, let alone a movie made by Sony! If you want a decent Slender Man story, go look up Marble Hornets or Everyman Hybrid on YouTube. You want a good horror film like this about creepy imagery and a cursed video, go watch the Ring. If you want to watch a good horror film about scary white people, go watch Get Out! I can kind of recommend this movie if you want to watch it with friends and rip it apart as like a bad movie night. But even then it's not really all that much of a fun bad movie to watch. It's just flat out bad. Don't waste your time! But if you do, just imagine every time the bell rings, it's really just Taco Bell and Slender Man wants his victims to try their new Nacho Fries. And nothing is more scary than eating Taco Bell!

Slender Man is truly one of the worst films I’ve seen in years.  The writing is clunky and on par with a first draft, the acting is stiff and phoned in, and there’s little sense of direction to be found anywhere in the movie.  Slender ManSlender Man is truly one of the worst films I’ve seen in years.  The writing is clunky and on par with a first draft, the acting is stiff and phoned in, and there’s little sense of direction to be found anywhere in the movie.  Slender Man himself looks like he’s wearing a sock over his head.  Unfortunately, this movie is a complete flop in the horror department as well.  When they’re not unintentionally funny, the scares are mostly flat and lame (but don’t worry, the movie compensates with obnoxiously loud music).  Even if you get scared at first, you probably won’t get scared by the end, because this movie is as repetitive as all get out.  As an example, there’s a certain scene in which a character gets scared by Slender Man and then wakes up in bed, only to immediately get scared and wake up again.  Seriously.  It’s enough to make me wonder if this film is intentionally bad, because I can’t imagine that anyone who was making this film thought this was passable.  Above all, this “movie” is a feeble attempt to cash in on an internet trend that faded into obscurity long before the movie came out.

It has its moments, but Slender Man is ultimately a dull affair.What is really disappointing is that the first ten minutes or so are pretty good. We are introduced to the four main characters. (One of the positive points of Slender Man isIt has its moments, but Slender Man is ultimately a dull affair.What is really disappointing is that the first ten minutes or so are pretty good. We are introduced to the four main characters. (One of the positive points of Slender Man is its actors.) The dialogue and pacing is pretty good, but then things just fall apart. There are a lot of dull scenes of the characters talking, arguing, and investigating without much interaction with anyone else. It doesn't help that the rules to Slender Man are vague and confusing throughout, and the exposition is delivered haphazardly. The ending in particular is a muddled mess.To its credit, the actual scares in this are pretty good. They do manage to capture what makes the Slender Man so scary in the first place. There are some really impactful visuals. The director is an artist when it comes to spooky forests and having Slender Man fading in and out of the background. (Although on the other hand, there is an annoyingly large amount of close-ups.)As spooky and nice looking as this movie can be, the good bits are just too few and far apart. I can't recommend this.

5.7/10 Honestly people are being way too harsh to this film calling it the 'worst horror they'd ever seen", and just being completely extreme and vague in their "criticism" without actual legitimate explanations why they hated it. While it5.7/10 Honestly people are being way too harsh to this film calling it the 'worst horror they'd ever seen", and just being completely extreme and vague in their "criticism" without actual legitimate explanations why they hated it. While it definitely isn't a good film overall, it's about the best portrayal you could expect from an internet horror concept which is essentially a very creepy tall faceless figure that takes children and is seen in old pictures that have been clearly photoshopped. The concept is creepy but really has no complexity or depth. This film at least delivers that same ominously bizarre atmosphere with sparing shots of Slenderman with the simple plotting and overall themes. You cant really expect a plot that goes anywhere with that simple subject matter. The film does drag on in between the creepy scenes with the annoying actresses brooding on in their personal terrors. Another huge problem is that Slenderman shows up maybe a total 2 min of the entire film combined, and the scares are very cliche and standard when he's sparingly featured. There is one sequence in the library that is done properly and has a considerable amount of decent scare ambition. The sound design and effects were firing on all cylinders throughout the film and created some very good sonic tension at times. There was also a considerably solid amount of solid camerawork throughout. Before you know it the film is over and the finale is ok at best but very abrupt. This film is the epitome of middle of the road cliche horror with some decent ambition at times, and is in no way deserving of such an embarrassing low rating.

If you are a horror fan, you should probably see this film. It is not very good, but it is interesting to talk about what went wrong with other fans later. But if you just want to go to the movies for some entertainment, this film is not forIf you are a horror fan, you should probably see this film. It is not very good, but it is interesting to talk about what went wrong with other fans later. But if you just want to go to the movies for some entertainment, this film is not for you. The worst thing about it is the script. Things happen that are vaguely connected, but nothing actually “develops” like a movie plot should. The cinematography, especially out in the woods, is interesting, but the rest of the locations are pedestrian – and there are probably too many closeups. On the other hand, I have seen the four lead actresses in “indie” films, and they are all very good and interesting to watch. Everyone else is forgettable. Finally, the “slender man” is not very scary, information about him is garbled and confusing (the fault of the script again), and he should never have had any closeups because he was obviously a guy in a costume – and not a very interesting costume either.

Wow. Coming from someone who wants nothing more than to find the good in even the worst scare flicks, this is one impressively unaccomplished movie.To take a character this ripe for cinematic portrayal and wind up with such a veritableWow. Coming from someone who wants nothing more than to find the good in even the worst scare flicks, this is one impressively unaccomplished movie.To take a character this ripe for cinematic portrayal and wind up with such a veritable carnival of paint-by-numbers blandness is truly a notable feat. There is some moderate visual flair and some not-bad-at-all cinematography in this movie, but it all gets put to waste by the complete poverty of innovation.I'll be honest, I didn't make it past the 60 minute mark. So it's possible that it picks up later, but even if the last 20 minutes miraculously turned into an Exorcist-worthy climax, no moviegoer should be forced to sit through the preceding two acts to get to it.

So...I'm a bit of a film snob, and a dyed-in-the-wool horror fanatic. In recent years I've migrated more to video games, since horror movies don't scare me that much any more. That said: I would love to see a list of "better" or "moreSo...I'm a bit of a film snob, and a dyed-in-the-wool horror fanatic. In recent years I've migrated more to video games, since horror movies don't scare me that much any more. That said: I would love to see a list of "better" or "more original" horror movies released in the past few years, from the slew of people calling this movie "bad".Sure it doesn't hold a candle to "It Follows", and "A Quiet Place" is certainly a good deal more ambitious, but...c'mon. SERIOUSLY. Where are all the great recent horror films that justify giving this film a 1 or 2 out of 10?    I found it all quite dignified and restrained - things are mostly kept in the realm of the psychological - and it has some of the best "teen" casting I've seen in years (i.e. I could actually tell the characters apart). If you expected a horror film of the ilk of John Carpenter's "The Thing", you're a FREAKING EEJIT.Given the current cesspool that is modern mainstream cinema, I'm giving it a 7.5 (rounded up to an 8 for this site, just to spite you all). Gimme this over a Marvel movie any day of the week.

A group of friends decide, in a house of one of them during the night, to summon the slender man starting of a link on the internet, and some time after that they start to have nightmares, seeing things in the woods and after a bit sometimeA group of friends decide, in a house of one of them during the night, to summon the slender man starting of a link on the internet, and some time after that they start to have nightmares, seeing things in the woods and after a bit sometime one of them disappear without any clue of what happened, then the friends go and do their own investigations to find out what could have happened. Directed by Sylvain White and written by David Birke.The story of this movie is very simple and cliche, it just don't have or increment any new thing in this kind of movie, even the prologue of everything is cliche and a bit ridiculous if you think a bit about it, like, they watch a video in some website and close their eyes, them they are cursed, this is so little creative and repetitive in movies like this. There are some moments that the characters do some dumb thigs, they make pretty clear that they can't uncover their eyes in one moments and see SlenderMan or they are going to be mentally destroyed somehow, and after 10 seconds one of the characters does this exact thing and one second later all of them with the same thing. The movie try to give some possible ways to combat the monsterm, but it is so weak the way that they did it, one of them get to one place to take something, them she takes it and it got mentioned one other time, but it does have zero influence during the course of the movie, it didn't made any sense. The conclusion of the story is also pretty down, like characters saying one thing and doing another, it got so slow in a point that it didn't even scare you anymore, this a high problem in this movie, the script could have been a bit better done and creative. Another big problem in this movie, is that, that the characters aren't much relatable in a way that you would care and cheer for them, there isn't much development for them, and the little bit that happend it didn't really implies in you caring for them, cosidering that this movie is about people in dangerous and not about the monster, they had to make we care for them to this work better, unfortunately it didn't worked out in this way.The sound of the movie are great, for real, they are done with maestry, there are a lot of moemnts during the movie that i got scared, and it was very thanks to the sound design here, it is very similar to sound that happened in the game from years ago, a very strange and messy thing, wich did represented in sound the creepy and crazy creature very well, the sound in the forest, the details that they did applied in the audio section, made this movie be scary.One thing that they did here and it gave us very nice moments, is the suggestiveness, in a lot of moments you see a shadow or a tree, and you be like that it could be that or not, it is good, letting our mind work to see something or not, that did happened a lot witht the characters to, just that in some moments it was very ridiculous, but mainly at the start of the movie, it did worked out very well.The acting is not the best neither the worst. Joey King did a very nice character, the problem is that she didn't had any development, the little that i cared about her, it was because of the actress. Julia Goldani had a bit more emotional moment, i think that she did well in some moments, but mostly of the movie she had a poker face that didn't pleased me very much. Jaz Sinclair also had the most cliche faces during some moments, unfortunately she didn't had much time to work or room to do different things.The CGI is awful here, like it is the worst 10 million dollar budget cgi ever, they did turned the light out of the movie in a lot of moments, wich could have been good to hide the bad cgi, but even with that, the cgi is so exposed and so bad and fake that when they show him, the fear kind of go away, because it is so fake, the creature naturally have a strange form and could scare people easily, but the did invented somethings here with the trees that just didn't worked for me.The movie was working better when the thing was being more of a mental situation, but when they decide to show and interact with the monster physically, things stop working.

I know it's late to make a Halloween Specials, but here we are!Okay, Slender Man was one of the most anticipated movie of 2018.. I enjoyed playing the game and listening to these urban legends about him, but this movie was.. EH!!!!
Just toI know it's late to make a Halloween Specials, but here we are!Okay, Slender Man was one of the most anticipated movie of 2018.. I enjoyed playing the game and listening to these urban legends about him, but this movie was.. EH!!!!Just to know, this review is gonna be a funny review actually.Slender Man is directed by Sylvain White, written by David Birke and starring Joey King, Julia Goldani Telles and Jaz Sinclair.The story is about a group of girls summoning Slender Man and when he got summoned, one of them gets missing, and the others trying to run away from him.. this is the whole story!Now, that's what I call a horror-pranks film, it's full of unscary scenes, with Slender Man pranking these girls.. or poor girls.. how did you talk all these pranks from a man without a face?First of all, let's count the dumb choices in this movie...1. They summoned Slender Man from a website, by a link says "SUMMON HIM". I mean what kind of creatures can be summoned from a website?2. To "summon him", you must watch a video and follow the instructions in the video, and when you're done, congratulation, Slender Man is summoned, go and have fun with him!3. Slender Man is a good pranker! He made me laugh a lot with his pranks... What's dumber than making a pranker creature in a horror movie?4. Oh, yeah, the cast was dumber than Slender Man.5. Slender Man, please, grow up.. stop playing with the trees, it's noisy!!6. The CGI of Slender Man was like a man with some toilet paper rolled around his face.7. This message is for the developers of this "game", please, fix the glitch of the faces, and the horror-dreaming stuff.8. One more thing, please, fix the performances too, cause they are bad!9. The finale.. LOL!10. And now, the dumbest thing in the movie award goes to... The script! Congrats to the script, it was super-dumb!WOW, this movie is terribly bad! As I said, it was one of the most anticipated movies of the whole year, but it disappointed me very very much! It easily became one of the worst movies of 2018 -if it's not the worst already-!One more thing, why Katie's father thinks that "people can not just disappear"? Wake up, MR. There's something called kidnapping, didn't you hear about it?I think you already know what I'm gonna give this terrible movie, don't you? Yup, it's definitely an F!!Okay, guys, thank you as always for reading my review, let me know if you like my reviews or not, and I welcome all the comments.

rt_summary: Small-town best friends Hallie, Chloe, Wren and Katie go online to try and conjure up the Slender Man -- a tall, thin, horrifying figure whose face has no discernible features. Two weeks later, Katie mysteriously disappears during a class trip to a historic graveyard. Determined to find her, the girls soon suspect that the legend of the Slender Man may be all too real.
meta_summary: In a small town in Massachusetts, four high school girls perform a ritual in an attempt to debunk the lore of Slender Man. When one of the girls goes mysteriously missing, they begin to suspect that she is, in fact, his latest victim.
